messageBody:
It looks like JB already covered a number of issues, so I'll just say that I have taught Java to some folks here at work during a regular lunchtime session, and we did everything test first. These were COBOL programmers trying to bring their resumes up-to-date and they had no problem with the concept of test-driven development.

Although, funnily enough, one just asked me the other day: "so, how do you run code after you've tested it?" Oops, I guess you can overdo the emphasis on testing! :-) Needless to say, we had a quick lesson on the joys of the main() method and actually running code from a commandline rather than a test harness.

As an aside, for non-trivial currency transactions, a dedicated money object that handles different currencies would be a better bet than either longs or BigDecimals.

Simon

>I hope to use JUNIT to teach programming to my Y1 students this year.
>I'd planned to write the test class, then ask the students to write
>the code e.g for a Book class, a test in the TestBook class might
>look like this.
>
>public void testPrice()
>{
> Book b1 = new Book();
> b1.setPrice(7.99);
> assertEquals(7.99, b1.getPrice(), 0.0799);
>}
>
>Sudents should write the set and get methods and set values
>correctly so this test is passed.
>
>Problem : - I want them to work through the exercises and tests one
>at a time, but the test class will obviously not compile until all
>of the correct methods are in place in the Book class.
>Is my approach to this incorrect. Is there better way?
>
>Hope you can help.
